addressed PR comments
@kaijianding, do you have any thoughts on https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3307#issuecomment-237303827?
fixed by #3269

The error message is fixed for both groupBy v1 and v2 by #3338. The avalanche of error messages is fixed for groupBy v2 by #3268. I think v1 still would have an avalanche of errors, but IMO that is wontfix since we are moving towards v2. If anyone disagrees with that feel free to reopen and fix it yourself :)

thanks @erikdubbelboer for the report.
I believe this use case is addressed by #3270 through "dimensionOrder": "numeric".

üëç
LGTM, :+1:
Looks like we have a few +1 and no objections, so I'll merge this as discussed in the dev sync today. thanks everyone!
üëç
@sirpkt can we finish this up for 0.9.2 release?
This looks great!

@gianm 
For #1, I agree we can use columns instead, and if user want do extraction, he can do it in his own code after  he gets the data . Even if he do want the extraction in druid, we can add the function back in another PR.
For #2, we can always use QueryGranularities.ALL, and remove granularity argument from the query.
For #3, I define `ScanQuery extends BaseQuery<ScanResultValue>` , the events data is wrapped inside of ScanResultValue, I can change event to type `Object`, then this Object can be List or ValueVector or Arrow. Another thing is that it need a http request header to tell the QueryResource to use some kind of more binary friendly protocol to transform thing like [{"segmentId":"xxx", "offset":offset, "events": "the binary here(List or ValueVector or Arrow)"}]

I missed that there may exist extensions that implement CacheStrategy.
I think it's better to rollback the interface change and make another issue to discuss about changing the interface.
In my thought, current CacheStrategy interface lacks consistency between methods.
computeCacheKey() explicitly requires query while prepareForCache(), for example, in GroupByQueryQueryToolChest assumes the existence of the associated query.
üëç
@nishantmonu51 any more comments?
Similar issue here. Any suggestions?
Can you elaborate on what query you are doing that gets these results? (topN, groupBy?)
nevermind :) groupby given the multiple dimension spec
I'm pretty sure Dimension tuples should roll up together in a groupBy.
Uh, I'm not sure I understand what you mean by Dimension tuples being rolled up. Could you elaborate, please?

@gvsmirnov, your query is grouping on two multi-value dimensions ('key' and another one 'value' created from key). Since Druid explodes multi-value dimensions when grouping, that means you get the cross product out.

I think what you're looking for is for Druid to treat 'value' as something derived from 'key' and not as a separate independent dimension. You might be able to do that with a custom extraction function that does basically `f(x) = x + ":" + lookup(x)`, and then only including the extracted dimension in your grouping (not the original one). Or by patching the existing lookup extraction function to have an option to prepend the key.
üëç
I would expect each combination of dimension values to appear only once, as per your expected behavior.

@gianm You made a lot of improvements in the groupBy engine for an upcoming release, does this strike you as an unintended side-effect somewhere? and do you know if the new grouper does the same thing?
@gianm that was my idea for the workaround, too. Brushing aside the kludginess, this would not work for non-injective lookups where one wants to group by the value that was looked up.

I miss-read the report.
Does `{ "key": "key2", "value": "value1", /*...*/}` have anything in it?

it looks like it is rolling up dimension tuples, but you just have more tuples than you expect

@drcrallen this seems to me like intended (but possibly unintuitive) behavior. But both engines do the same thing where any multi-value dimension gets independently exploded, yielding a cross product. I just wrote a PR with a new test for that: #3415

@gvsmirnov if you're wanting to group by the looked up value on a non-injective lookup, you probably don't want to include the key at all, right? Since it would potentially vary and interfere with the grouping. So you could use the version/option of the extraction function that doesn't prepend the key in that case.

Ok, I get it now, thanks @gianm for that good test.

I was wrong previously. Due to the fact that the multi-value dimension is both value1 **and** value2, the behavior presented by druid and shown by @gianm in tests is the correct behavior as groupBy stands today.

This definitely deserves to be called out in docs.
Given that the multi-value dimension takes on both values, @gvsmirnov, can you elaborate on what kind of behavior would be helpful?
It does no good to return a bunch of data that isn't actually useful or intended.
üëç after travis
To clarify: I believe the helpful behavior would be to only return rows where the looked-up value corresponds to the look-up key.

@gvsmirnov can you see if https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3367 captures your needs adequately? it would be worth commenting there that you have a use-case for multi-value dimensions. If that does capture the needs correctly I propose closing this down as working as intended (confusing though it is) and having only one issue for "id and value" being returned for lookups.
Also a part of the sadness of the workaround: if you want the looked-up value to match exactly to `xyz`, you cannot use a simple `selector` filter.

@gvsmirnov putting the key in the source lookup is probably not the best way to go, for the all reasons you mentioned (extra data in kafka, interferes with filtering, can't be disabled, etc‚Ä¶). I was thinking more like an option in the extraction function for prepending the key, which you could enable or disable at query time.

Specifically I was thinking of something like, `"includeKey": true, "keyDelimiter": "|"` as things you could ask the extraction function to do. That would probably solve #3367 as well. It wouldn't be as nice as returning a real JSON object but it would be easy to fit into the existing system.

One important thing here is that the dimension you group by and the dimension you filter by do not have to be defined the same way. You could filter by value and then group by "key:value", and that would work fine.
@gvsmirnov what would the query result look like in that case?
One possible solution: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3414#issuecomment-243818758
If you give me a few pointers on where to start, I'd be ok to implement it while avoiding clubbering everything around :)
Moving milestone as author has not responded
üëç

If you wanted to do the extractionFn options, they could be added to RegisteredLookupExtractionFn, LookupExtractionFn, and LookupDimensionSpec (the three internal ways lookups can get used). It might be nice to generalize them a bit, i.e. rather than having keyDelimiter, instead have a "format string" that could be something like "%k:%v" or "%v (%k)" or whatever. Perhaps also an option to escape keys/values to handle the case where it's not possible to select an un-ambiguous format string.

I think your multiOutput suggestion is not implementable right now, since dimension values currently need to be strings. We are working on lifting that restriction but there's a bunch of internal refactoring needed. It would be a good long term solution though.
@kaijianding do you have any benchmarks around how fast data can be read using this query? Can we compare it against select? I suspect the difference will be substantial
Minor formatting changes and I suggest reverting `LookupDimensionSpec` unless the change is required for this PR and it is fully tested.

I looked this over and it looks very good to me.

One main comment is that the query doesn't use the processing pool and hence will not respect query priorities and may have multi-tenancy impacts but I am still in favor of the approach taken. I think we need to note that in the docs at a minimum.

üëç  after docs are added

I almost want to move this up to 0.9.2 :P
I think this extension will benefit more from battle testing by interested parties rather than further review. Good job @b-slim
@kaijianding @KurtYoung is this still WIP? It looks ready
Why not wait til 0.10 to make it default?
@cheddar we can do that, i think the performance benefits are worth it, but we can push this back to 0.10.
üëç
I guess we could also make it default now and then use 0.10 to delete the old code?  If you guys trust the code, that is.  I know we haven't run it in prod yet, so I cannot say too much about it.
@cheddar we haven't run it in production either, which means whatever version this goes in will have an extra-long validation period.
Which I'm OK with, but just want to set expectations on release schedules.
on a side note, if this is going to be around and/or discussed for a bit, can the originating branch not be in https://github.com/druid-io/druid ? having a branch named "default" is not ideal.
I can close this for now, it has compilation problems anyways
still addressing PR comments from @gianm, marking as WIP temporarily

I added `mapName` field in `LookupDimensionSpec` and `RegisteredLookupExtractionFn`
and updated docs to reflect the change of Globally Cached Lookups.
I also modified the description about Lookup Extraction Function
because LookupExtractor no longer supports `"namespace"` type.
üëç

FYI, i was able to run druid with a secured Kerberos/Hadoop cluster with loading both hdfs module and hadoop dependencies separately and without having any extra path on the actual classpath.
Second for the TGT key, it is true that if you run kinit once before starting druid, the hadoop libs will keep renewing that  TGT ticket by running `kinit -R` (so i guess no need to export any envi variables), although TGT tickets usually have a limited life time (by default 7d i guess), so you have to run again `kinit -kt keytab user` and `kinit -R` won't work. Having https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3419 in, should slove the problem of re-running the `kinit` periodically.
üëç
do we need to make similar changes to hadoop job also ?

@nishantmonu51 this is enough if user is using hdfs storage module. If not i guess we would have to add that to jobs as well. Although i am not aware if there is a use cases where you have hadoop with Kerberos without hdfs. Anyway we can add that in the future if we have a request for it.
I agree with @nishantmonu51 that we should add to jobs as well. It'll be a lot less confusing to the user.
The use case I was thinking was to use hadoop jobs with S3 as deep storage instead of HDFS, where you may possibly use batch ingestion without having hdfs-storage module.
@nishantmonu51 but at that use case is there any Kerberos in the picture ?
@b-slim it is possible to read raw data from HDFS and write segments to S3
Addressed PR comments from @gianm
Implemented in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3148
If we have multiple chief, submit each chief's query runner  to the  same request thread. it will be serial.
Thanks @mark1900 !
awesome!
@mark1900 these all need appropriate copyright headers. Check out the other files in druid to see the correct POM and JAVA headers
To be complete this should also include https://github.com/metamx/java-util/pull/50, i. e. changing `java-util` dependency to the next snapshot in druid.
@leventov FYI, we have https://github.com/metamx/bytebuffer-collections that has a bunch of the "fast int list" funcitons in it.

@drcrallen didn't see anything like IntIterator in this repo. There is also `io.druid.collections.IntList`, but it also doesn't provide IntIterator abstraction.

This change doesn' require half of the `fastutil` library, probably just a couple of hundreds LOCs.

To make it clear, the question of this issue is -- is it worth to make a PR improving IndexMergers performance (according to IndexMergeBenchmark, how relevant is this to overall performance is also a part of the question), but also introducing some complexity? If it is, should the PR use fastutil (maybe with minimizing/shading?), or copy logic into Druid?

Another concern is changed `IndexedInts` API (`Iterator<Integer> iterator(); -> IntIterator iterator()`, is this interface designed for subclassing in Druid's extensions? Fastutil's `IntIterator` is a subclass of `Iterator<Integer>`, so external usage of `IndexedInts` shouldn't be an issue, only subclassing.
@fjy buildV9Directly is irrelevant to this issue?

@mark1900 this needs docs in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/tree/master/docs/content/development/extensions-contrib . Make sure to mention https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3421#discussion_r77415080 since this PR (unlike the other metadata extensions) does not package the driver's jar by default.

@leventov IndexMerger has two aspects of immediate interest: 1) cpu-time 2) heap pressure

If a PR improves one or the other in a measurable way without sacrificing either, then it is worth bringing in. Ingestion and batch time resource usage are important.
